pros: There is nothing at all good about this place. Study at Manchester University instead.
cons: 1. Students are being regularly exploited on the AVD course especially for industry group design projects and staff's own promotion opportunities. 2. Staff only recite from books and have very little 'real-world' aircraft design experience and are only half interested in spending time with the students.  3. Research projects are virtually none existent for many except a chosen few. 4. Management is a disgrace with the place being very poorly run by a narcissistic lecturer who causes trouble whenever he can and anybody more senior than him is expected to comply with everything he says. 5. Senior management and the head of centre are absolutely clueless about what is really happening here on a daily basis.

review_title: Great Facilities and Team, Management Could Be Improved
pros: Cranfield has some incredible facilities and the courses they offer are truly exceptional. Plenty of opportunities for staff to view and even use the world-class facilities. There are lots of social functions and generally a very positive employer, with good pay in line with or better than competitors. Staff are generally positive and pleasant.
cons: Management seems to often be quite separated from the entry-level and mid-level roles. Feedback, when gathered, is often not acted upon which leads to significant resourcing and operational problems down the line. Workload is sometimes unrealistically large and staffing issues problems often go unresolved for far too long as consequence of team happiness or performance. Great progression in some departments, but in others no consideration is given to possible options which led to poor retention of staff within my team.

pros: Staff, Resources, Training, Exposure, Communication
cons: Poor work life balance, Stressful, NA, NA, NA

review_title: Terrible place to work in: Very strong hierarchy
pros: There is nothing good about working at Cranfield University.
cons: The hierarchy at Cranfield Uni is very strong. It does not feel like you are working at a university in UK. As a research fellow you are made to feel insignificant. One of the head of schools have also made a joke at a meeting of professors (where research fellows were also present ) that 'if you do not want to work get funding so that we can use that money to hire research fellows and make them do the dirty work for you'. On top of that, because of the strong hierarchy you cannot take a lead on any projects (even though you are told that you are expected to ) without the approval of everyone involved. I have also faced numerous sexist and racist remarks from my managers or colleagues. A few of the other research fellows have faced as well. No one even bats an eyelid when these comments are made or protests because, obviously the hierarchy is quite strong. The HR is terrible as well, they kept interfering in my personal life without any reason. The campus is okay, but because you are stuck in the middle of nowhere, there are not a lot of eateries/ shops. I have worked at multiple universities, but Cranfield Uni has one of the worst working culture. There are also not a lot of prospects for promotion, if you are working as a Research Fellow.

pros:
Extremely generous holiday entitlement 
Pension and life assurance 
Good Work life balance 
Great car parking provision
Flexible working arrangements but governed by local decisions so depends where you work
cons:
Poor leadership and lack of strategic direction
Very weak senior and middle management
Horrendous approach to staff engagement 
Innovation a used slogan, incapable of any form of change management 
Any form of cross departmental planning and coordination non-existent 
Managers promoted internally by virtue of service years who do not realise what team management covers
Instilled sense of confidentiality as a cover up for poor decision making

review_title: Awful treatment from service departments and bad culture
pros: The university is located in a beautiful countryside with large campus offering good parking and nice views. The real jewel (although, causing some problems) of the campus is the aerodrome, where in good weather you can just enjoy looking at the aeroplanes during your lunch :)
cons:
Very bad income driven and business like culture, where the university stops being the university and becomes a consultancy. That is exactly what happened to this one. Many groups forget how to generate their own ideas and find their own external funding for research but rather purely rely on large companies funding their research, which is obviously also dictated by these companies. This situation definitely causing serious issues with lack of research freedom as the researchers are not allowed a single step outside the scope set by funder (who have specific business agenda).
The remote location of the campus is also a bad thing because to get to the closest reasonably sized supermarket or any other services takes at least 15-20 minutes by car or 30-60 minutes by bus. This is causing serious troubles when you need to solve some personal problems during lunch, because it is not possible (not enough time).
The employment contract is rather strange in this university. In normal universities (most of the UK) they never specify working hours and even the FTE equivalent number of hours per week is usually notional as you are required to fulfil your duties, but when and how many hours you will spend for this nobody cares and in most cases you are not required to be at the working place from 9 to 5 every working day. Here it is different. The contract specify working hours and many groups and departments actually enforces them. So, even in the regime of work it is more like a commercial consultancy than a proper university.
When I was joining the university, I was accepting one job title and it turned out that it was changed later on without my knowledge. And because there is no proper job description, the work actually turned out to be on absolutely different topic, which I am not particularly interested in.
I was also trying to find support for applications for external funding and could not find any, although was trying to contact various departments... They said that it is not in the core direction of the university and nobody will support it here...
Finally, my contract is coming to an end really soon and by law (I found it later, but still on time) this is considered as a redundancy nevertheless what your arrangements outside your relationships with your current employer. And the employer has to pay you a Redundancy pay or offer similar (in terms of duties and pay) position, which you can (!) take. What the HR in this university was trying to do was to make me to write a resignation letter for the end of my contract saying that I have found another position after this one and this is not considered to be a redundancy. DO NOT WRITE OR SIGN ANYTHING!!! This is actually violation of the law from their side. Remember, you do not have to write and/or sign anything! And I mean anything. Consult ACAS if you are asked to write or sign any document during your employment!!!

review_title: Great University, but some staff only care about box ticking
pros:
- The university has great facilities and the service staff are all friendly and helpful.

- The general reputation of the universities academics is deserved.
cons:
- Some (not all) professors only care about box ticking and paperwork, they show little interest in students as human beings. 

- The campus is in the middle of nowhere with pretty poor transportation to the major cities near by, and limited activities on weekends.

- Local student accommodation off campus is over priced and not good quality. Landlords are usually rude and unhelpful.

pros:
Brilliant for networking with senior managers in blue-chips, NFPs, government
Therefore great for academics who want to make a difference
More collegial than most: people are willing to help each other
cons: Can be hectic. If you want a quiet life to write papers and do minimal teaching, probably not right for you. It is possible to do high-grade (and highly relevant) research - and indeed the research access can be easier - but it's quite a juggle.

job_title: PhD Researcher In Aerospace in Cranfield, England
pros:
- Location is ideal for studying. There is a good reason they call Cranfield the "Monastery of Engineering" - it promotes devotion to the subject one has chosen to master.
- The Staff is truly knowledgeable. They will often have surprisingly useful and insightful advice in any kind of difficulties (e.g. when working on a multi-national, multi-corporate projects or dealing with project complexities).
- Sport, wellbeing and recreation facilities are excellent. There is a huge list of clubs and societies to cater for the most extravagant preferences (e.g. an astronomical society, a walking club, a gliding club, yoga, martial arts etc.)
- Cranfield is truly considered serious in the industry around the world. I've worked with Cranfield grads holding expert positions at companies in the UK, in mainland Europe, or even in Canada and Australia. This is indeed a place to be if one desires to become part of the world's most advanced Aerospace community.
cons:
- To the individuals used to the hustle and fumes of the big city being out in the green fields may seem boring or depressing. But again, the remote location is a huge benefit if one comes here to devote their time to do proper research. Having a car or at least a bicycle is highly recommended.
- While the staff is knowledgeable and true experts in their fields involved with the top-notch industry projects, they are very busy with teaching the Master students and spending time with them. Thus, they expect the PhD students to express significant abilities for autonomous work and self-management. While it IS expected that a PhD student is self-motivated and able to work well on their own, only consulting their supervisors when the most critical issues arise (it is highlighted in the book named "How to get a PhD"), some of the less-mature or guidance-dependent students may regard this as one of the most significant challenges.
- Prepare to work hard. Whatever project you get onto, it seems that Cranfield is pushing it to the limit and expects very high productivity out of its students, whether MSc or PhD.

review_title: Ok for 2 years as a post doc.
pros:
Flexible working arrangements with friendly staff. Some very interesting projects to work on if you get on the right team. 

Also, if you want a hybrid between research and industry, this is definitely a good place to be.
cons: Lack of career progression for early career researchers/research engineers. Most new appointees are from outside the University. There have been people in post-doc roles for over 7 years with no view for promotion. If coming here and you are ambitious, I would advise leaving after 2-3 years or you might get career stucked.

pros: Very flexible environment, flexible working hours, very closed links with certain industries ( engineering, economics, management), quiet environment without any distractions (this could also be a con), good value for money, perfect from Lecturer level and above,
